reality.  The proof of his escape was his message to the officer (to whom 
he was reporting to) at the end of the movie.  He entered a sort of 
alternate reality where he and his new gf didn't die on the train.﻿

+Bruno Alves The machine didn't create an alternate reality in terms of 
another machine. It doesn't work that way in the context of the film. 
Whenever the Source Code activates, it creates a new reality wherein the 
events on the train take place as they were depicted. It split the real, 
legitimate timeline and created a parallel universe as many times as 
Coulter went back in. Rutledge alludes to this fact earlier in the film, 
but doesn't expand on it. Turning off the Source Code wouldn't "turn off" 
that reality. The Source Code was something like a matter transportation 
system that resulted in split timelines.

+JMPesce A machine created an alternate reality, turning off the machine 
would terminate said reality from reality, the same way turning off your 
computer will terminate any virtual reality.

+Nihilism 
1- When you play a PC game (a program), you're somewhat participating in a 
virtual reality, if you turn off your computer, said reality will end, the 
only place it may continue existing is inside your imagination, which 
exists inside the universe... etc. Regardless, any of these said 
"realities" i've mentioned depend on their SOURCE; killing the guy will end 
his "imagination" just like turning off (cutting the energy source) a 
computer will cease any program from working. 
2- The 2 hour logic the movie creator presented is flawed, thus the movie's 
universe is illogical, any offscreen explanation will provide you with 
understanding but it won't correct that 2 hour universe.
3- The technology is based on the concept of "memory", unless this differs 
from our REAL LIFE deffinition, it can't deffy our REAL LIFE logic. 
4- If the ending/movieuniverse requires any kind of offscreen explanation 
from the movie creator IN ORDER for you to get it's logic, it's a bad 
ending.PERIOD.

+Smilin Observer Exactly, she didn't understand it at all. Rutledge didn't 
realize that he had created an alternate reality machine, and every time 
the Source Code operated, it created a new reality in which the train did 
or did not explode, along with the repercussions of that situation. When 
Colter solved the crime and took matters into his own hands within the 
Source Code, he effectively re-wrote history in that alternate timeline; 
the train never explodes, he saves lives, he lives happily ever after. Or 
does he? See, the film is supposed to have the illusion of a happy ending, 
but one of the last shots in the film is the camera passing by this 
reflective bean statue that Colter is standing in front of. When the camera 
passes by, we see that he still looks like Sean Fentress, and he will 
always look like and be expected to know things that Sean Fentress did. It 
opens a whole set of new questions entirely, which is what makes the ending 
to Source Code eerie and unsettling. It's a superb film.

sea. From here he could have either swam back to the island (if close 
enough) or he could have even had a small boat/vehicle waiting for him. Now 
as for the reason why the ending is actually illogical. The reactor in the 
film is a nuclear fusion reactor, go read about nuclear fusion and then 
you'll realise why it's illogical.﻿

Most of these movies made sense, except batman, what do i mean by this, 
well in the movie batman visits fox who gives him "the bat" the flying 
aircraft used to save Gotham and is told by fox that auto pilot needs 
fixing, This is important because he fixes the auto pilot as confirmed by 
Mr. Fox at the movies end, which confirms that batman could have put the 
"the bat" on auto pilot and eject. So that section covers how he could have 
escaped, and ejecting miles from the explosion be nuclear or not would have 
been well outside the blast radius and could have swam to shore which is 
possible as it is depicted in the league of assassins training in the 
comic's. As to why fake his death, during the movie Alfred tells Bruce that 
he took a vacation every year "hoping that across from his table he would 
see Bruce they would say nothing but Alfred would know Bruce had made it." 
Cause Alfred saw the pain that gotham had brought to bruce and trouble it 
brought him and wanted him to live a life free from it all. After Alfred 
falls out with bruce and leaves, bruce realises that he has given 
everything to gotham and he has achieved the goals he set out to accomplish 
as batman so in classic batman style he disappears neveer to be heard from, 
but appears across from alfred so that he can give alfred some comfort in 
the way alfred comforted him as a child." Also clues are left to the main 
class gordon, alfred, fox and robin that he is still alive so that if 
gotham ever needed batman, batman would always be there looking over the 
city as depicted by the statue which was shown in an overlooking positon. 
It also went towards the pop culture that batman although not having super

A some points regarding a couple of these movies:

Batman: This movie made absolutely NO SENSE WHAT SO EVER. First, Bane 
breaks his back, and sends him to a prison which is supposedly inescapable

sketchy credentials and zero diagnostic equipment PUNCHES HIM IN THE SPINE! 
If anything, this movie should be about the miracle man who can cure 
paralysis by punching people in the spine!

#2 The giant hole of a prison is, at best, a medium level rock climbing 
wall. There were hand holds from bottom to top created by the spaces 
between the bricks. And even if there weren't, there were no guards!

limbs should have been stuck in that prison.

I disagree that the ending of the *The Dark Knight Rises* was illogical.

In *The Dark Knight*, Alfred warned Bruce of pushing the limitations of the 
Batman. Bruce wanted the city to be saved, which his actions in *The Dark 
Knight* accomplished, with the Harvey Dent Act being passed that 
successfully prevented most crime. Even though the Batman took the blame 
for the deaths in *The Dark Knight* instead of Harvey Dent, the Batman was 
no longer needed for Gotham, which is why he didn't return until the 
arrival of Bane in Gotham during the events of *The Dark Knight Rises*. 
Don't forget the injuries Bruce had accumulated as the Batman. The Batman 
was able to establish homeostasis in Gotham after having his back broken 
and returning to Gotham to stop Bane and Taila al Ghul. Gotham had become 
peaceful again, Bruce had probably been pushed over his physical 
limitations with Bane, the Batman's legacy had been restored, and Bruce led 
John Blake into the Batcave to take up the mantle should Gotham need the 
Batman again. There were plenty of reasons for the Batman to fake his 
death. Perhaps the only illogical thing about that is if John Blake does 
become the Batman, retconning in the public eye their view that the Batman 
had died, but I think this shows that the Batman is a symbol greater than 
death. That, and Bruce could stop the posturing as a famous celebrity by 
living away from Gotham, assuming no one in Paris could recognize him.

In fact, a better candidate for an illogical ending would be *The Dark 
Knight*, since Gordon and the Batman could've pinned Harvey Dent's murders 
on the Joker, perhaps.﻿

Source Code was a strange movie, but it is in a sense, a 'time travel' 
movie. Jake G's character is put into the memory of another man to see who 
blew up the train and why. However, he has free will. Since he's  
'remembering' this, this makes another timeline. Quick lesson on time 
travel. three possibilities:Fixed timeline; meaning no changes can be made 
e.i. you kill Hitler as a baby, but his parents have another one that 
become Hitler anyway; a Paradoxical timeline i.e. you kill your granddad, 
so you're never born to kill your granddad; and a Multiple Timeline. The 
latter is the case with Source Code. In the reality that they send the main 
character to find out how the train blows up, it still blows up, BUT in the 
version where the main character stops the train exploding, that action 
creates a NEW timeline where he now exists.  sorry for the long post


tl;dr  the guy saves the day because timey-wimey wibbley-wobbly stuff.﻿

This video may have overlooked the subtlety of the ending in "Source Code". 
Was it necessarily implied that he went on living a real life? I think it 
meant to suggest that his consciousness continued into a perceived life. If 
he'd been truly alive again, he would have awoken in the facility where his 
brain was hooked in. I consider that the ending was messing with the 
concept of how powerful the brain can be at perceiving a dream state as 
full reality. My conclusion allowed these possibilities as well: that he 
was either unplugged and just died and they went with the whole "heaven" 
thing, or that his consciousness manifested a continuation of his life, 
manipulating time in his head to satisfy him before he inevitably died 
anyhow. Imagine a dream where it felt like 60 years of life within that 
period of consciousness, and you have what I think happened at the end of 
the movie... but it only happened for him in his mind, and he's still dead 
from our perspective.﻿

The trees in The Happening weren't emitting poisonous gas... The plants 
finally adapted to the modern and industrialized world that man was 
creating, and began to perceive humans as a threat. Plants have defense 
mechanisms just like any other form of life.. Some ward off predators, 
poison other animals that want to eat them, putting out odors that deter 
predators, grow barbs to deter animals from passing over them and trampling 
them in the progress, or even eating animals. There are a number of plant 
adaptations that deter predators/dangers. Plants developing the capability 
of producing a chemical that (when inhaling pollen) causes delirium or any 
other sort of mental dysfunction isn't impossible. They already cause some 
to have allergic reactions... They could produce any number of toxins, even 
some that could cause the brain to swell, which would cause the desired 
effect needed in the film. It was kind of a let down, but it did make 
sense, and the entire point of the film was to alert people of the dangers 
of destroying the environment Industrialization of nature and deforestation 
are big problems, along with plant gene manufacturing/breeding/altering, 
and chemicals we pump onto them, as well as overall contaminants we pump 
into the environment.  Not that plants might actually kill us all, but we 
are codependent. We produce CO2, they produce Oxygen; we need oxygen and 
plants need CO2.

So, my sister made me watch Divergent. Most of it wasn't too bad, but the 
ending had major issues. I'm about to drop some spoilers, so if you care 
about that, stop reading. If you haven't seen the movie, most of this won't 
make sense anyway.
-------------------START OF SPOILERS-----------------
[I apologize in advance for changing tenses throughout]
Before I get to the ending's problems, I'd like to point out that the aim 
of the story was to empower teen girls, the target audience. But the guy 
that gives the main character arbitrary performance points likes her. 
Translation: Let your male superiors get touchy-feely so you can get ahead. 
Considering that one of her biggest fears was him overpowering her 
sexually, it implies that she didn't fully trust him.
Here we go.
After the obedience serum injections, executing Divergents is an objective 
of those following the Erudites. This is made clear when Eric shoots the 
one who was walking between the rows of soldiers at the base. Later, Eric's 
buddy mentions that they "can't let a single Divergent through". Keep that 
in mind.
Eric and his buddy notice Four walking by, and Eric gloats to him, even 
though he's essentially brain dead at this point, but I'll let that slide 
because he's a jerk. Tris then reveals herself. She aims her gun at Eric, 
who aims at Four, who aims at Eric's buddy, who aims at Tris. In that 
instant, Eric turns his head to see who it was. In that instant, Four 
should've simultaneously shot Eric's buddy and dropped to the ground, 
allowing Tris to shoot Eric.
Instead, they're in this Mexican Standoff, which was unnecessary because 
Eric has a small army walking around him. It's later shown that there were 
security cameras all over the area, yet apparently no one realized that 
there was a problem. Anyway, after their banter, Eric spins to grab/move 
Tris's rifle. This guy is supposedly highly trained, ranking as a leader 
and instructor. BASIC SELF DEFENSE dictates that you move the barrel AWAY 
from yourself, to the side (in this case, to his left because his buddy was 
to his right). Instead, he points it DOWN toward his genitals and gets shot 
in the leg. Then Four, instead of shooting Eric's buddy in the head, waits 
a full second after Eric spun to knock the guy down instead.
Tris and Four run. Tris is shot in the shoulder by one of the two guys that 
they let live for no reason. Tris and Four are almost immediately 
surrounded by soldiers. One of the two guys yelled "Don't move, drop your 
weapons." Do you think Nazis at the concentration camps would be so 
courteous to armed Jews? Their orders were to EXECUTE DIVERGENTS.
Eric and his buddy take Tris and Four to Jeanine, the mastermind. I 
expected them to be severely reprimanded for disobeying execution orders, 
but nope. Instead, Jeanine monologues the plan, needlessly gets within ARMS 
LENGTH of the trained combatants, Tris and Four. When Four says "[She's] 
not as smart as [she] thinks [she is]," he wasn't kidding. They're soldiers 
trained to improvise. If either of them had a weapon up their sleeve, she'd 
be dead.
Four is taken away for experimentation, while Tris is taken to a field for 
execution for no reason. Bodies littered the streets. It's not like anyone 
was worried about making a mess. Instead, three soldiers with rifles made 
Tris kneel. One of them then had to look down his sights with one eye for 
at least four seconds. She's two feet away. It's an execution, not an 
interrogation or hostage situation. Considering that the bad guys are 
concerned with efficiency, this doesn't fit. It wasn't moral hesitation 
either. It was a lack of competency.
Tris's mother shows up to save Tris as Deus Ex Machina, but is killed 
minutes later. Tris meets her father, who was an untrained pacifist, and 
some other survivors including her brother. Her father rushes ahead of the 
group in an apparent suicide so he can be remembered as a hero. They 
would've been better off saying he was killed early in the invasion.
Later, Tris finds Four drugged, right next to the inner sanctum of the 
entire operation. Jeanine shows up to gloat that they can now control 
Divergents, and again comes within close proximity to Tris. Other soldiers 
semi-surround Tris and Four. Jeanine needlessly lets Tris and Four fight. 
They clearly had the technology to make a dart gun that fires injection 
shots. They would've had another super soldier on their side.
During the fight, Tris picks up a pistol. The guards hold their fire for no 
reason. Tris gives Four the gun and is able to bring him back mentally, and 
he fires on the enemy soldiers. A team of trained soldiers with rifles 
can't take out one guy with a pistol. Some bad guys attempt hand-to-hand 
combat, even though they have pistols. They moved forward, choosing to 
close the distance, even though they knew how well Four was trained.
Outside, the troops were rounding up civilians, preparing to execute them 
in groups. This was unnecessary, considering that they fire on any that 
run, and had killed civilians as they were entering the area. They 
should've been sweeping the area, shooting anyone at will. There's no point 
in setting up groups.﻿

dollars all over the globe under fake identities IOT support his crime

story of recovering from sexual assault told in a scifi action thriller."

hated about the works. Why does Transformers 3 have a very similar

that might of been something they would of really liked. Its just my

things more than it needs to be. IMO They should just stick with key points

Source code does not end in that "They disconnect him from the source code 
so he just stays in the train which is now the new reality". It ends by 
revealing that the source code machine is much more powerful than it was 
previously thought. It was thought that it simulated events happened in a 
recent past to a level of detail in which the universe is completely 
constructed, and that is sustained by the machine. However, at the end, it 
is revealed that this created universe is not actually simulated by the 
machine, but just summoned and observed, being completely independent from 
the machine once it exists.  The subject, who's consciousnesses is sent to 
the body of a person in that event, is allowed to travel between bodies 
thanks to the machine, but once he's disconnected, he's stuck in one 
universe.﻿

+DoubleOscar
Dude, no need to hold on to every straw. Just face it that Interstellar was 
a basic SciFi-movie that made science up where they saw fit and with a, in 
my opinion, pretty ridiculous ending. Do you really want to tell me that 
this movie could happen in real life? Just like that? Up to 60 years from 
now? Seriously?

Sure they could exist along a black hole, but could they still be habitable 
and a promising replacement for Earth? Common sense says: Hell no! As I 
said, they shouldn't even have any natural light.

Yes, I understood that. It just made no sense. The whole plot didn't. If 
they had the technology to reach Saturn in about 2 years AND to put 
astronauts into stasis for even much longer, why jumping into another 
galaxy then? We have already tracked very promising Exoplanets in our 
cosmological neighboorhood. Why not checking them out?
But no. It must feel headscratching complex so that people scratch their 
heads and say: "Wow, that's really complex!" So they came up with the 
humans from the future-thing which was just ridiculous.
How can there even be humans in that future? I thought they all were 
supposed to die out due to climate change on Earth? And how can one 
"master" five dimensions? Via technology? And if so... heck, how FAR in the 
future are they? And why would they still care about their ancestors who 
suffered from stone age problems?
If those humans have the technology to build artificial wormholes and four 
dimensional places INSIDE black holes... couldn't they think of a simpler 
solution while they are on it? Like giving the humans the magical black 
hole data themselfs? Like just sending a message: "Hey guys! This is us - 
you - from the future! We remember you having some issues with this climate 
change thingy. So here's how it goes!"
No, instead those humans chose a girl who they assumed would be able to fix 
everything and who just happens to have a father with just the right 
experience to fly into a wormhole to another galaxy, where he is supposed 
to take a cannonball into a black hole, where he could give her that data 
in the past through moving books and dust and... in the end... somehow come 
out of it and... see her die.
...I can't believe peeps are saying that Phantom Menace was badly written. 
God, Interstellar has more logical errors than I can count!

First of all, he wasn't a space ghost thing, he was just Cooper. Second, 
things can survive a black hole if their trajectory is not directly through 
the center (remember Gargantua was a "Gentle singularity") and they are 
moving fast enough to not be ripped apart by the tidal forces. Hence, why 
Cooper survived his journey and fell into the tesseract.

As for the planets, it IS possible for planets to exist along a black hole. 
The accretion disk can create enough heat to sustain life on surrounding 
planets.

Back to the "space ghost thing," did you listen to the dialog? Cooper was 
sent to the tesseract inside the black hole by Human of the future who have 
mastered 5 dimensions (meaning that they see time as a physical dimension 
and have access to it.) Cooper was chosen by them because he was they only 
candidate in the human race to have all of the qualifications (I.e. Space 
travel experience and a strong enough bond with his daughter)

I suggest reading Kip Thorne's book the Science of Interstellar. It 
explains how everything is based on his research and he was so much more 
than just "Executive Producer" on set.

scientific does that sound? Aside from that nothing can go inside black 
holes AND survive. The gravitational forces would rip everything apart. 
That weird robot was even supposed to send data from INSIDE the black hole.

Then there are numourus planets around the black hole and for some reason

long anyway, so yeah... that was a pointless endeavour.
And I could go on. Again: All this wouldn't normally matter to me in a

Holy shit you don't understand the Dark Knight Rises ending. Bruce has 
always told Alfred that he wants to live a normal life, and he wants to 
enjoy his life, away from his terrible memories at Gotham (because of his 
parent's deaths). Alfred wanted this for him as well. 
At the end of The Dark Knight Rises, Bruce fixes the autopilot on the Bat, 
then has it fly out to the ocean on it's own, as he fakes his death. At the 
beginning of the film, Alfred said to Bruce that he always imagined seeing 
Bruce across the cafe that he goes to for vacations, enjoying is life. 
Finally, Alfred sees Bruce and Selina Kyle there, and Alfred shakes his 
head to Bruce, and Bruce does the same back. Alfred leaves happy, because 
he knows that Bruce is finally enjoying his life, and is no longer Batman. 
You also see "Robin" find his way into the Batcave at the end of the film, 
suggesting that he is going to take up the mantle.
P.S Bruce did NOT die at the end. Bruce and Selina were eating together, 
and Alfred didn't even know they were together,therefore he wasn't 
imagining it. Also, Nolan has said publicly that Bruce survived in his 
film.﻿

+Slogan Wade Well the way catheters work would make that very difficult. I 
never intended for this to turn into a serious discussion so if you don't 
care then don't worry about it.

But if you do then see catheters usually work using "gravity" and "suction" 
rather than the person themselves. This is done in one of two ways, if the 
person is ambulatory then they can use a smaller system because with them 
being able to sit and stand they're creating a natural means of gravity 
pulling downward, but even so the bags are usually half as long as your 
arm. BUT if someone is bedbound or otherwise immobile it requires a bedside 
unit where suction is created by creating an unequal pressure on the side 
they want it to come to (ever pulled filled one container with air and put 
a vacuum in another and then connected them with a hose back in science 
class? It's a pretty common grade school experiment and as I'm sure you can 
guess even if you didn't the liquid will be sucked in by the empty space in 
the other container. It's a lot like that, just a practical application and 
not a middle school science experiment). But this method would be out as it 
requires a small box unit at the bedside to maintain this pressure system 
while the individual is bedbound. The first method could potentially be 
hidden as there are people who have to use these systems in everyday life 
(usually towards the end of life or if they have issues before they have an 
ostomy placed), BUT the problem with that is it relies on the individual 
being active enough that gravity alone can fill the bag. And as we know 
he's laying down the entire movie and doesn't have much clothing on to hide 
it.

Of course I accept it's just a movie and don't find it a big deal, it never 
bothered me. But I was simply explaining I understood why it was mentioned.

OMG! do you even pay attention to the films you watch? The only movie here 
with an illogical ending (And actually entire premise) was "The Happening". 
The twist ending of "Saw" is explained if you watch the sequels as they 
reveal that Jigsaw's protege Amanda helped him set up the game of the first 
film and he game himself a drug to induce a temporary death-like sleep, and 
every scene in the original where he was not in that room was a flashback. 
"A Nightmare On Elm Street"'s ending is explained because at the end of the 
movie Rooney Mara's character, Nancy, discovers the only way to defeat 
Freddy is to bring him back into the real world and kill him. After 
supposedly killing him, she is taken home by her mother (and what happens 
when you bring an immortal dream ghost into the real world?) we realize the 
rules have changed and now because he is REAL he can kill people while they 
are awake, meaning there is no escape... But there is also an alternate 
interpretation, Nancy has never woken up from her nightmare and is forever 
trapped in the dream world with Freddy. "The Dark Knight Rises", one word, 
AUTOPILOT. The ending to "Robocop" reveals that the love and strong 
willpower of a human being can overcome any robotic programming. 
"Prometheus" if you really pay attention reveals throughout that a war was 
waged between different factions of the Engineers, the good ones who 
believed humans still have the potential of becoming a better race, and the 
bad who want to wipe us out. Dr. Shaw (Noomi Rapace) and David (Fassbender) 
go out in search for the good Engineers to understand why the bad ones want 
to destroy us. And finally in "Source Code", it is revealed that through 
multiple times of going into the source code, little things here and there 
are changed and causes a different outcome through each simulation. This 
leads Captain Stevens (Gyllenhaal) to notice that this is more than just a 
simulation, it is a whole new world, and in realizing he is trully dying 
and only kept alive through life-support, he enlists the help of one of his 
employers/captors(whatever you want to call her) to permanently transfer 
his consciousness into the source code to save everyone on the train and 
take him off of life support, so he can then live within the source code. 
There, if you still do not understand the endings of these films I cannot 
help you.﻿

OK. The 3 illogical interpretations in the video: 

One, In Dark Knight rises, Wayne installs an auto-pilot in the bat without 
Fox's knowledge. So the way he escaped could be by putting the the bat in 
auto, jumping into the sea way ahead of the blast at the same time some 
distance from the land, so that no one saw him.

Two, he faked his death, not to take a vacation or stop being batman, he 
did it so that he can show the people of Gotham that if he, who owes 
nothing to the city, can give up his life to protect it, then they too can 
be heroes of their own and protect each other, thus hoping to becoming a 
symbol of hope, strength and selflessness. 

Three, the main catch in the movie Source Code is that, even though the 
inventors of the virtual reality believe its just a computer program, it 
turns out that they have actually created a gateway into parallel 
universes. This is clearly understood from the the last message that 
Gyllenhaal leaves for Farmiga. So each time he goes into the virtual 
reality, he is actually visiting parallel universes(not past, cause both 
worlds exist at the same time and his decisions in the new world doesn't 
seem to have an impact on the real one) , where the timeline is running 
behind the real (his world) one.

Though one mistake that can be pointed out in the movie is that, in the 
parallel worlds where he visits, he is in the body of a school teacher. Now 
the question that can be asked is, where does the teacher actually go if 
his body is used by Gyllenhaal's mind.﻿

proceeded to let all the most important people in his life know that he was 
still alive.

 Alfred explains earlier on in the last film that he never wanted Bruce to 
return home. He wished instead to, while on holiday in Italy, sit in a 
cafe, order an espresso (A holiday he goes on the same time every year, 
during which sits in said cafe drinking an espresso at the same time each 
day.), and look across the cafe to see Bruce with a wife, happy.  They 
wouldn't talk or register each other's presence, just notice each other. 
 Now you see that it wasn't a random encounter, it was set up by Bruce.  

The guy Morgan Freeman plays (can't remember his name) finds out because 
when the plane is returned to him, he's told the autopilot now works.  (We 
are told when the plane is revealed that the autopilot doesn't work, and 
Bruce tells people that he has to ride the plane out because the autopilot 
doesn't work.  He's lying, of course.)  This then explains how he faked his 
death - by putting the plane in autopilot.

Dark Knight actually *does* make sense -- Bruce/Batman faking his own death 
is the only way he can truly divorce himself from his life in Gotham as 
well as provide the city with the spiritual-hero that they need (while, 
tangentially, opening the door for "Robin" to replace him as 
Batman/Nightwing/whatever).  As for the "probability" of certain things 
happening as they did: it *is* a superhero movie, which means that it by 
definition doesn't have to have things work the way they do in Real 
Life(tm). Not only can improbable technology/powers exist but narrative 
occurrences/influences, as well. (Now, could it have been a *better* 
ending? *That's* a completely different discussion. But he ending, as it 
stands, isn't illogical at all.)﻿

"Smokin' Aces" is my number one illogical ending not for mere common 
film-world improbability, but for its sheer disjointedness for the very 
film it's supposed to end. It's the greatest example I know of a 
twist-that's-not-a-twist-at-all:

The FBI's whole plot ordeal is to save Buddy "Aces" Israel so as to gain 
the insider info he has on the Mob. From the very start all the FBI agents, 
including Messner and his partner, know the effort is about saving a guy to 
get insider mob info.

Turns out in the 'twist' that FBI bosses really just want Buddy as the 
donor to save the life of another guy: Sparazza.

Agent Messner is so upset that so many died, including his partner, just so 
the FBI would get some info, that he pulls the plug on both patients, 
killing them and thus screwing the FBI from getting that insider info. 

Problem? Again, mob info was always the point. Changing who provides that 
info literally changes nothing for Messner and this 'big reveal' should 
have no impact at all. Yet Messner acts stunned, betrayed, lost. 

His dialogue makes clear it's the cause for saving the person, not the 
person saved, that he feels betrayed over, but to really drill the point 
home: he himself pulls the plug on both patients, so that should end any 
idea that maybe those two mattered to him. 

IF anything the bigger fish the FBI wanted [Sparazza] means the dead agents 
died for more valuable info. Maybe Messner would have been upset to find 
everyone died to get a small-fry, smaller than Buddy, but finding out your 
medium-boss [Buddy] was swapped for a huge-boss [Sparazza] should if 
anything help to console him that the info was even more worth it. 

I have always just figured the original script must have differed so much 
that this twist ending was actually a twist, but with rewrites nobody 
stopped to think that the ending itself needed rewritten.﻿

a sin for something like only 30 seconds passing on the timer despite three

+Setanta Life You take movies to literally and seriously bro. Its fiction, 
not reality tv. Movie time is perfectly legit in this environment and can 
be used effectively and strategically for suspense purposes. Just look at 
the Jason horror movies. Dude is slow as hell yet he always manages to 
catch up to people running away. If we use real time, he'd just be some 
lame slow poke.

+Setanta Life just because the movie cut from Bruce to a timer with 6 
seconds left does NOT mean they happened back to back. The cut to Bruce 
could have been a full minute before the device detonated, and the jump cut 
to the "6 seconds" timer could have been much further ahead in the 
timeline. Like right now, I'm sitting in a chair in my living room. If my 
life were a movie, and the next major plot point in the movie involved me 
going to the grocery store, the movie could jump cut to me walking in the 
aisles of the store. Is it logical to assume that I teleported to the store 
directly from my living room chair? No, because it's understood that there 
was a great amount of time left out between the two scenes- time that I 
spent getting my shoes on, starting my car, getting onto the freeway, et 
cetera. Just because two cuts are back to back in the movie itself does NOT 
mean they occurred back to back in the movie's timeline. The same principle 
was probably in effect in this scene.

Knight and it ejected the Batpod? He probably built the Bat along the same 
lines and designed the cockpit to separate (while the rest of the ship 
continued flying on autopilot. Then it's just a matter of the cockpit 
having some lift capability and rockets to thrust Batman some miles away 
from the explosion site. He was monitoring the countdown in the escape pod, 
hoping to make a survivable distance.

remaining funds anyway since he's "dead") : When Bruce was still Batman - 
and a billionaire - he would have put multiple stashes of millions of 
dollars all over the globe under fake identities IOT support his crime 
fighting. 

So Bruce quit as Batman. He's still rich (Just not super rich.) And he's 
happy with Selina. He just wanted to let the Man who raised him know that 
he was alive and happy.

The Matrix has an illogical premise that I finally noticed after watching 
it several times.  One of the huge dangers faced by the characters is that 
the machines can "cut the hardline."  There is no hardline--it's entirely 
virtual.  In the movie we see a pair of clippers cut a phone line, but that 
phone line is in the virtual Matrix, not the destroyed city on the surface. 
 Morpheus tells Neo that his ship the Nebuchadnezzar broadcasts a "pirate 
signal," but either way, they cannot broadcast (airwaves) into a closed 
system like the Matrix.  The Matrix is a program running in hardware, so 
the "Neb" would have to physically connect to data cables, and those cables 
would never be in the sewer system, they would be protected by an army of 
sentinels just like they are in the third film.  Oh, and when Thomas 
Anderson is flushed from the power station, the Neb pulls up and plucks him 
out of the water uncontested?  Morpheus should have been yelling at Tank to 
get them the hell out of there, because they would have been surrounded by 
sentinels carving up the Neb with lasers.  I cannot watch the Matrix again 
with these glaring mistakes!﻿

them. She could go back to Earth, but the fact she chooses a different path 
than what you would do doesn't make it wrong. Geez!
E) Batman didn't just fake his death to "go on vacation". Firstly, vacation

directly following the scene you mentioned. Also, I saw it as him admitting 
he probably wasn't best for Gotham himself so he decided to give it room to 
grow.

In conclusion, watch the movies and actually pay attention before making a 
list so you don't look at dumb as you do right now.﻿

Also (again), the Robocop mind-over-programming thing was because in the 
new one, they did everything in reverse. In the original, Robocop had his 
programming in full, just to have it slowly being taken over by his own 
memories and personality. In the remake, he started with full memories, 
just to have it slowly replaced with the programming.

At the end, to save himself and the civilians, his programmer deactivated 
the chip that forced him to follow the programming, this releasing his 
mind. The boss was unattackable thanks to the red tag, but Murphy's loyalty 
to his family overwrote his programming, allowing him to force himself to 
pull the trigger. If you pay attention, you'll also notice it is his own 
hand, not the robot hand, that does the firing in that scene, again 
signifying that it is the human that is in control, not the programming.﻿

If you know anything about serial killer psychology, the ending to Saw was 
fantastic. Serial killers like to watch and be involved in their games. Not 
to watch on a screen from far away, but to be right there involved in the 
game.

Also, if you actually watched the movie, there's a huge reason that body 
needed to be there. He makes a note that the "blood" on the floor is 
poisonous. This lets Gordon (a doctor) know that he can dip the cigarette 
in the blood and give it to Adam so that he can kill him with it. Also, the 
victims turn off the lights and whisper to each other at one point so the 
camera can't pick up the audio. If Jigsaw hadn't been in the room, they 
would have gotten away with tricking him into thinking Adam was dead.
